data.message: Add gitignore rules
Add license documentation
[tests] Framework for unit testing
[model] Add Organizations and Domains to the model
[exceptions] Add BaseError class
[model] Set organization and domain properties to NOT NULL

[database] Add Database manager class

This class is responsible of managing the access to the Sorting Hat
database. Currently, it only supports connect() and clear() methods.

[register] Add add_organization() method

This method adds a new organization to the registry. If the organization
already exists, it raises an 'AlreadyExistsError' exception.

[register] Add add_domain() function

This function adds a new domain to the available list of domains
for that organization. Orgaization must exist and domain has to
be unique. Otherwise, the fuction will fail raising exceptions.
[model] Set Organization class to load domains in eager mode
[register] Fix typos in documentation
[register] Add registry() method to list the available organizations

[register] Add delete_organization() function

This function allows to delete organizations and domains associated
to them. To delete the domains in cascade, the Organization model
was changed to include this new feature.

[register] Add delete_domain() function

This function allows to delete domains associated to organizations.
Both, domain and organization must exist in the registry.
[api] Rename register module to api module
[cmd] Command class to run commands

[cmd:orgs] Add Organizations command class

This command will list, add or delete organizations and domains
from the registry.
In its current version, the command only prints to the standard
output the list of available organizations/domains.

[cmd:orgs] Support to add organizations and domains

Organizations command is able now to add organizations
and domains in the registry.
output the list of available organizations/domains.
[tests] Check buffered mode in TestOrgsRegistry unit tests

[cmd:orgs] Support to delete organizations and domains

Organizations command can now to remove organizations
and domains from the registry.
output the list of available organizations/domains.

[cmd] Update Command interface

Two new properties were added: description() and usage().
In addition, run() method was updated to receive the params
using a list instead of a dict.

[cmd:orgs] Implement run() method

This method lists, adds or deleted organizations and domains from
the registry. Command arguments are parsed using 'argparse' lib.
Additionally, description() and usage() methods were implemented.

Unit tests updated for testing this new functionality.
[cmd:orgs] Update documentation

[cmd:orgs] Support '--ovewrite' option on '--add' action

This option allows to overwrite existing relationships between
organizations and domains.

Unit tests updated.
[exceptions] Add BadFileFormatError exception

[cmd:load] Add Load command class

This command will import on the registry a set of organizations and domains
from an input file.
On its current version, the command defines 'import_domains' method
that reads a file and imports a list of domains/organizations.
[tests] Unit tests for load command
[cmd:orgs] Improve help messages
[cmd:orgs] Raise RuntimeError when invalid files are given
[cmd:load] Improve output feedback while adding domains

[cmd:load] Add run() method to Load command class

This method add domains and companies to the registry.
Domains are read from the standard input (default method)
or from a file.
Additionally, description() and usage() methods were implemented.

Unit tests updated for testing this new functionality.
[cmd:load] Improve command documentation
[cmd:load] Fix error parsing unicode strings

[cmd:load] Update regex to allow any character on company names

This allows to have companies with characters like &, /, \, ",
and so on. This excludes format charactes like tabs or new lines,
among others.
[database] Force connections and tables to use UTF-8 encoding
[cmd:load] Support inline comments on domains-companies files
[sortinghat] Add script used to run the tool
[sortinghat] Read parameters from a configuration file

[database] Manage database connection errors

Database class raises a 'DatabaseError' exception when
an error occurs connecting to the given database.
[sortinghat] Print runtime error messages

[cmd] Command __init__() does not set up database connection anymore

Database connection has to be established calling _set_database()
method during the initialization of the subclass.

[cmd:config] Command to read and write configuration parameters

Nowadays, this command support get() method, to read parameters
from a configuration file and, set() method, to write configuration
parameters on a file.

Unit tests created for these methods.
[cmd:config] Implement run() method
[sortinghat] Add config command
[model] Add UniqueIdentity and Enrollment models

[tests] TestBaseCase for model tests

This class defines common setUp and tearDown methods that will be
used by model tests.
[model] Fix typo in UniqueIdentity class

[api] Add add_unique_identity() method

Method that creates a new unique identity in the registry.
If the identity already exists, it raises an 'AlreadyExistsError'
exception.

[model] Change the name of the identity relationship on Enrollment

The name of the relationship between unique identities and
enrollment was set to 'user'. The name has been changed to
'identity' because it is more accurate.
[model] Define default period dates using datetime objects
[model] Add 'delete on cascade' action

[api] Add add_enrollment() function

The function adds a new relationship between the unique identity
identified by 'uuid' and the given 'organization'. The given
identity and organization must exist prior to add this enrollment.
The period of the enrollment can be given with the parameters 'start_date'
and 'end_date'.

If the given enrollment data is already in the registry, the function
will raise an exception.
[tests] Check delete on cascade when removing organizations

[api] Add delete_unique_identity() function

This function deletes a unique identity from the registry.
If the identity is not found, a NotFoundError exception is
raised.

[tests] TestBaseCase for api tests

This class defines common setUp and tearDown methods that will be
used by api tests.
[api] Update class documentation
[tests] Modify api import call
[api] Rename add_enrollment() date parameters
[api] Add delete_enrollment() function
[tests] Fix typos

[model] Change 'lazy' load to 'joined' on Enroll class

This change allows to access to related objects when instances
are detached from the current database session.

[api] Add enrollments() function

This function a list of enrollments, filtered by uuids or
organizations.
[api] Support date ranges in enrollments function

[cmd:enroll] Add Enroll command class

This command adds a new relationships between a identities
and organizations.

[cmd:enroll] Add run() method to Enroll command

This also includes description() and usage() methods and
parses arguments using argparse library.
[sortinghat] Add 'enroll' command

[utils] Add str_to_datetime() function.

This function formats strings into datetime objects.
In addition, InvalidDateError exception has been added.

[cmd:enroll] Support --from and --to parameters

Enrollment duration can be set using these parameters.
[tests] Fix typos

[cmd:withdraw] Add Withdraw command class

This command removes exinting enrollments from the registry.

[cmd:withdraw] Add run() method to Withdraw command

This also includes description() and usage() methods and
parses arguments using argparse library.
[sortinghat] Add 'withdraw' command
[sortinghat] Use SORTINGHAT_COMMANDS dict to manage available commands
[tests] Add test to check 'from_date' <= 'to_date' in 'enrollmets'

[cmd:log] Add Log command class

This command lists enrollments from the registry.

[cmd:log] Add run() method to Log command

This also includes description() and usage() methods and
parses arguments using argparse library.
[sortinghat] Add 'log' command
[api] Order enrollments by end date too
[model] Change 'company' by 'organization' term
[model] Change 'upeople_companies' by 'enrollments' table
[sortinghat] Improve help documentation
[model] Change 'upeople' by 'uidentity' table

[model] Add Identity class to the model

This class will be used to model the different set of identities
that a unique identitiy could have.
[model] Add unique constraint to 'uuid' field in UniqueIdentity

[api] Add uuid() method to generate universal unique identifiers

At this moment, the UUID will be the given email, name or username,
following that order. Future version of the function will use
SHA-1 to generate the UUID.
[utils] Move uuid() function to utils module
[utils] Use SHA-1 to generate UUIDs

[api] Add add_identity() function

This function allows to add new identities to the registry and
assign them to unique identities. By default, this function also
creates a new unique identity each time that a new identity is
added.

[cmd:add] Add Add command class

This command adds new identities into the registry.
[tests] Check whether ids are also removed on delete_unique_identity()

[cmd:add] Add run() method to Add command

This also includes description() and usage() methods.
[sortinghat] Add 'add' command

[api] Add unique_identities() function

This funtion list the unique identities available on the registry

[database] Fix 'Too many connections' error

In SQLAlchemy, when a session is closed using close() method, it
is not really closed. It is sent to a pool of connections. That is
why 'Too many connections' error was raised.

To avoid this, each session has to be deleted from the pool
using NullPool class.
[model] Set 'joined' load to unique identities

[cmd:show] Add Show class command

This class shows the relatated information to unique identities
available in the registry.

To print the output, the class uses 'jinja2' library. This library
will be used by the rest of the commands to print the output.
[sortinghat] Add 'show' command

[cmd] Add display() method to print command output

This method uses templates to print the output of each command.
The template library used to do so is 'jinja2'. Error and warning
messages do not uses this library by now.
[cmd] Improve commands output
[cmd:load] Use display() method to print the output

[tests] Ignore jinja2 import warnings

Ignore jinja2 warnings when it tries to import its 'tests' module
using relative imports.
[tests] Use REGISTRY_EMPTY_OUTPUT in test_add_without_args()

[cmd] Add error() and warning() methods

With these two new methods, commands will print error and warning
messages to stderr.
[model] Use uuid as primary key in UniqueIdentity class
[tests] Fix typo in test name

[model] Assign unique identifiers to identities

Identities will have two ids, a unique identifier based on SHA-1
and the uuid which the identity is assigned to.

[api] Add delete_identity() function

This function removes the given identity from the registry.
[api] Update documentation
[tests] Add missed joins to some queries

[cmd:remove] Add Remove command class

This command removes exinting unique identities or identities
from the registry.

[cmd:remove] Add run() method to Remove command

This also includes description() and usage() methods.
[sortinghat] Add 'rm' command

[api] Add merge_unique_identities() function

This function joins one unique identity into another.
[api] Support case on merging identities when both uuids are equal

[api] Add move_identity() function

This funtion allows to move an identity to a unique identity

[cmd:merge] Add Merge command class

This class allows to merge one unique identity into another one.
[cmd:merge] Add run() method to Merge class
[sortinghat] Add 'merge' command
[cmd:move] Add Move command class
[cmd:move] Add run() method to Move command class
[sortinghat] Add 'mv' command

[templates] Add end blank line to some teamplates

This proceduces a prettier output.
[sortinghat] Write runtime error messages to stderr
[api] Use same criteria naming unique identities and identities

[utils] Add merge_date_ranges() function

This function merges a set of overlaped data ranges.

[api] Add merge_enrollments() function

This function merge those overlapped enrollments related to
a unique identity.
[cmd:enroll] Add --merge option

[api] Check valid period ranges

MIN and MAX period dates are "1900-01-01" and "2100-01-01".
These were values for former DEFAULT_START_DATE and DEFAULT_END_DATE
variables.

[api] Add 'uuid' attribute to AlreadyExistsError exception

This attribute will be used in those cases when it is required
to know which is the uuid that contains the identity that already
exists (i.e api.add_identity() function).

[cmd:load] Support identities loading

Using the option --identities, data about identities and
organizations can be loaded on the registry.
Add setup.py script
Add README file
Rename README to use markdown file extension

[mg2sh] Script to export identities from Metrics Grimoire databases

mg2sh is a script that exports information about identities from
Metrics Girmoire databases (i.e CVSAnalY, Bicho, IRCAnalysis, etc).
The information is exported into a JSON object that follows the
sortinghat identities format.

[cmd:load] Set source of the identities

Using the option --source, the user can set in the registry
where the information comes from.
[tests] Define test base case for load tests

[cmd:load] Add class to load identities based on distinct formats

'IdentitiesLoader' is an abstract class defined to import identities
based on differnt formats. Some existing code from 'Load' was refactored
into 'EclipseIdentitiesLoader' class to import identities using Eclipse
identities JSON format.

New exception 'LoadError' has been also develop to raise errors when
something goes wrong loading identities.
[mg2sh] Fix typo in documentation
[cmd:load] Support for importing identities using grimoire format

[matching] Add IdentityMatcher class and factory function

Subclassing IdentityMatcher will allow to have distinct methods,
heuristics or algorithms to determine when two unique identities
are likely the same.

[matching] Add SimpleMatcher class

This matcher only produces a positive result when two identities
from each unique identity share the same email address. It also
returns a positive match when the uuid on both unique identities
is equal.

Unit tests also added.
[matching] Use dict to manage available identity matchers

[api] Add match_identities() function

This commit adds a function to search for the possible similar
identities currently stored on the registry.
[cmd:add] Add matching option when adding identities
[cmd:load] Add matching option to loading command
[tests] Return error code when tests fail
Add Travis configuration
Add Coveralls configuration
Add Coveralls badge

[api] Support top domains

With 'is_top_domain' flag, a domain can be set as a top domain.
This is useful to avoid the insertion of sub-domains which belong
to the same organization (i.e  eu.example.com, us.example.com).
This flag can be updated using 'overwrite' parameter.

Model and tests were also updated to support this new feature.
[cmd:orgs] Add '--top-domain' option on '--add' action
Update copyright info
[api] Add domains() function

[cmd:affiliate] Add Affiliate command class

This command automates the affiliation of exinting unique identities
on organizations.
from the registry.

[database] Add class methods for database management

This commits adds some class methods to wrap daily database actions
such as create(), drop(), execute() and build_engine().

[cmd:init] Add Init command class

This command creates and initializes an empty Sorting Hat
registry.
[sortinghat] Add 'init' and 'affiliate' commands
[tests] Fix typo in 'show' tests
Update README

[api] Add 'source' filter to unique_identities()

This new parameter allows to filter by source when the function
unique_identities() is called.
[model] Add to_dict() method to model classes

[cmd:export] Add SortingHatIdentitiesExporter class

This class exports the information about unique identities
stored in the registry, to a JSON formatted string.

[cmd:export] Add Export command class

So far, this class only implements export_identities() method,
that allows to export into a file the identities from the
registry.
[cmd:export] Add run() method to Export command
[sortinghat] Add 'export' command
[mg2sh] Pretty print for JSON output
[mg2sh] Move generic functions to db modules
[sh2mg] Script to link identities from Metrics Grimoire databases
[cmd:export] Sort identities by uuid

This class exports the information about organizations
stored in the registry, to a JSON formatted string.
[cmd:export] Support for exporting organizations and domains
[cmd:load] Rename domains options to organizations
[cmd:load] Add Gitdm organizations parser

[parsing] Create new package to store parsers

[parsing:gitdm] Use InvalidFormatError instead of BadFileFormatError
[tests] test_cmd_export case for empty domains lists

This method was also implemented by Gitdm and SorthingHat

[parsing:gitdm] Add default value for 'is_top_domain'

[cmd:load] Support several organizations input formats

The command can load different organizations input formats
without giving the input type. Currently it supports
SortingHat and Gitdm organizations formats.
Fix typo in README file
[parsing:gitdm] Fix unicode errors

[cmd:load] Set --identities and --orgs parameters as required

[cmd:export] Set --identities and --orgs as required parameters

[parsing:sh] Add SortingHat parser

This new class parses data from identites and organizations streams.
This will replace the previos parsers used to import data on
SortingHat registry.
This commit also updates the exporter to follow the nex schema.

[cmd:load] Remove third-party organizations loaders

SortingHat format is the only supported format. Third-party
deprecated loaders will be moved to a different tool.
[parsing:sh] Remove deprecated organizations parser
[parsing:sh] Set methods to private
[tests] Add new test to merge_date_ranges()

[cmd:load] Support new SortingHat identities loader

SortingHat schema is from the unique and default format
used to import identities and organizations. This commit also
removes the deprecated parsers and loaders used within this
command.
[cmd:load] Remove deprecated 'source' argument

[cmd:load] Load all content from the input file by default

By default, the command will load all the content from the
input file without excluding anything. That means the options
'--identities' and '--orgs' are not mandatory anymore but
can still be used to import a set of the data.
[parsing:sh] Use str_to_datetime() to parse date strings
[parsing:sh] Encode data to UTF-8

[cmd:load] Skip identities with None values
[cmd:load] Avoid to load first identity twice
[mg2sh] Do not export IRC identities which its nick is None

[matching:simple] Match on valid email addresses

This matcher will only give possitive results when the given
email address are valid. To check when an email address is valid
the next pattern is used: "^(?P<email>[^\s@]+@[^\s@.]+\.[^\s@]+)$".
[tests] Fix tests to check matches when UUIDs are different
[tests] Add test to match identities with the same UUID
[mg2sh] Fix unicode errors on identities ids
[parsing:sh] Add UUID values to identities
[sh2mg] Use SortingHat parser to parse input files

[model] Use nicks as ids when reflecting from IRC databases

The previous class used numeric ids but this was a bug. Currently,
there are not numeric ids on IRC databases. The identifier is the
nickname from the table 'irclog'.

[tests] Fix non-deterministic order on identities lists

For unknown reasons, SQLAlchemy does not return the list
of identities in the same order every time that the tests
are call. For this reason, we sort the list of identities
before checking their values.

[parsing:sh] Encode UUID and ids to UTF-8

Some UUIDs and idenfifiers can have string values instead of
integer values. For this reason, these fields are encoded
to avoid common unicode errors.

[matching:email_name] Add EmailNameMatcher class

This new method for matching identities uses email addresses and
names with the pattern "firstname lastname".
[matching:email] Rename simple matcher to email matcher
[utils] Fix error generating UUIDs from unicode values

[cmd:load] Fix enconding errors in command messages

[cmd:load] Fix new encoding error writting to stdout

[cmd:unify] Add unify command

This command looks for sets of similar identities using the given
matcher and merging those identities into one unique identity.

This file contains the list of countries defined by the ISO 3166

[matching] Define new methods on IdentityMatcher class

These new two methods are match_filtered_identities() and
filter(). Matchers are required to implement these methods
in order to support the new matching method.
[matching:email] Implement match_filtered_identities() and filter()
[matching:email-name] Implement match_filtered_identities() and filter()

[matching] Add match() - a generic matching function

This function implements a generic and faster matching
algorithm for unique identities. This function returns
a list of matched subsets.
[cmd:unify] Use match() function to unify unique identities

[cmd:mv] Support to detach identities

When 'from_id' and 'to_uuid' parameters are equal, the command
will be detached from its unique identity, creating a new
one with 'from_id' uuid. This only works when 'to_uuid' does
not exist.

[tests] Make some tests deterministic

[api] Add search_unique_identities() function

[cmd:show] Search unique identities using parameter '--term'

This new parameter allows to show command to search identities
using the given term. The term will be searched on name, email,

[sh2mg] Add index to UUID field on 'people_uidentities' table
[tests] Make deterministic more tests

[api] Check the existence of a UUID when a new identity is created

So far, add_identity() function only checked whether a tuple of
source, name, email and username existed on the database before
the insertion of a new identity. With this patch, the UUID is also
checked to avoid problems when tuples with the combination of
"None" and None values are inserted.
[parsing:eclipse] Add Eclipse parser
[eclipse2sh] Tool that converts Eclipse files to a Sorting Hat JSON file

[cmd:load] Fix bug on profiles when email addresses are filtered

As 'username' fields can store email addresses as values, it is
required to filter them as we do with 'email' fields.
[cmd:load] Set None instead of 'Unknown' on profile names

Commans will either return CMD_SUCCESS=0 or CMD_FAILURE=1 status

[cmd:init] Update CSV reader to support Python 2/3

In Python 3, the CSV reader needs a str object as input
and not a stream object. pkg_resources returned a stream
object so, it was needed to open the CSV file in text
mode. This method is compatible on both Python versions.

[api] Check identity id uniqueness in add_identity()

So far, sortinghat did not check whether the id of an identity
was already inserted in the database. It only checked if the
tuple (source, name, email, username) was stored. This might
raise some problems like in #67, when the values of an identity
are truncated because their length, so they were not found in the
database when they are compared.

With this patch this problem will not happen again because
for those cases, the UUID will be the same and a AlreadyExistError
will be raised. If for any reason the UUIDs are different,
it still have a unique constraint in the identities table that
checks if new tuples of (source, name, email, username) to be inserted
already exist in the database.

The problem with the length of the values will persist and
they will be truncated.

[database] Fix TIME_WAIT connections error

For unknown reasons, when an exception is raised when a
database connection is in use, the connection will not close
properly, leaving it in a TIME_WAIT state. If this happens
many times, for example when a huge amount of identities are
affiliated, MySQL servers ignore new incoming connections
util those open are closed by the kernel.

This behaviour only occurs using NullPool class. That class
closes connections, when a session is over. Replacing it by
QueuePool class fixes this issue because it reuses connections.

The use of this class raises the "Too many connections" error
when test cases are run (see 693837f for further info). This
commit also fixes the unit tests reusing the connections.

[cmd:init] Check invalid database names

[utils] Use case insensitive seed to generate UUIDs

So far, the identities UUIDs are generated using case sensitive
values with the seed (source:email:name:username). This means
that for an identity with the same values in upper or lower case
(i.e: jsmith@example.com and JSMITH@example.com) different UUIDs
are generated when the identity is the same.

This patch fixes this problem generating UUIDs ignoring the case
of the values.

Take into account that it produces an incompatibility with
previous UUIDs. These UUIDs must be regenerated.

[utils] Support unaccent unicode strings in to_unicode()

The option 'unaccent' has been added in to_unicode() function.
This allows to convert accent characters to their unnacent
canonical form. For instance, 'Ê, ê, é, ë' are considered the
same character as 'e' or 'Ĉ, ć' the same as 'c'.

[utils] Use unaccent name values to generate UUIDs

So far, the identities UUIDs are generated using accent characters
This means that for an identity with the same values accent or
unaccent (i.e: John Smith or Jöhn Smith), different UUIDs
are generated when the identity is the same.

This patch fixes this problem generating UUIDs converting this
accent character to their canonical form.

This change is caused by the behaviour of MySQL with unaccent
or accent characters. MySQL considers those characters the same,
raising IntegrityError exceptions when similar tuples with accent
or unaccent values are inserted into the database. Generating
the same UUID for these cases will prevent the error.

Take into account that it produces an incompatibility with
previous UUIDs. These UUIDs must be regenerated.

[model] Force 'utf8_unicode_ci' collation on MySQL tables

MySQL considers chars like 'β' and 'b' or 'ı' and 'i' the same,
when some collation values are set (i.e utf8_general_ci). This can
raise integrity errors when Sorting Hat tries to add similar
identities with these pairs of characters.

For instance, if the identity:

    ('scm', 'βart', 'bart@example.com', 'bart)

is stored in the database, the insertion of:

    ('scm', 'bart', 'bart@example.com', 'bart)

will raise an error, even when these identities have different
UUIDs.

Forcing MySQL to use 'utf8_unicode_ci' fixes this error, allowing
to insert both identities.

[matching] Fix error setting an empty list as default to blacklist

The declaration of the __init__ method, assigns an empty list
to 'blacklist' as the default paramameter. This is a common
error and must be avoided.

This commit fixes this problem setting None as a default
parameter for 'blacklist'.

[db] Fix tables created with invalid collation

In some random situations SortingHat tables appear with an invalid
collation. This is related to a wrong generation of the DDL table
statement by SqlAlchemy, which may randomly prepend the collation
information (mysql_collate) to the charset one (mysql_charset),
causing the former to be ignored. Changing mysql_charset to
mysql_default_charset fixes the problem.

[database] Use a optimistic approach when inserting data

With this optimistic approach, no more queries to check
whether an entity exists on the database are run prior to
its insertion. The new procedure works as follows:

  * Try to insert an entity without checking whether it exists in
    the database or not.
  * If the entity exists, an IntegrityError or a FlushError will
    be raised.
  * Rollback the transaction
  * Catch this error and check if it is an error raised by a
    duplicate entry.
  * If that was the cause, handle the error and raise an
    `AlreadyExistsError`.

Some changes were needed in `AlreadyExistsError` exception to
store the ID and the type of the duplicated entry.

[unify] Add resume method to unify command

This code proposes a method to recover failed unify executions.
In a nutshell, after calculating the matches in memory, they are
converted to JSON items and marked as not processed. Each match
successfully executed is marked as processed. In case of a failure,
the failed match plus the remaining ones are serialized to disk
(which location is fixed). In the next execution, those matches
will be loaded and re-executed again, if the recovery option is
enabled.

[db] Support UTF-8 fully in MySQL/MariaDB

The default charset of UTF-8 (utf8) in MySQL/MariaDB does
not support, even when they are part of the standard,
4-bytes long characters. This means characters like emojis
or certain chinese characters cannot be inserted. Usually,
identities names or usernames have these types of characters.

The charset that fully supports UTF-8 is 'utf8mb4' using the
collation 'utf8mb4_unicode_520_ci'. This collation implements
the suggested Unicode Collation Algorithm (v5.2).

Using 'utf8mb4' also implies that the maximum size of char
(VARCHAR and so on) columns is 191. Indexes cannot be larger
than that when using InnoDB engine.

This patch can break the database so it is recommended to
regenerate again the database from a dump.

More info:
  * https://dev.mysql.com/worklog/task/?id=2673
  * https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/charset-unicode-conversion.html
  * https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4

This one preserves the same structure but adds two new fields
to each object. These two new fields are 'created_at' and

the information stored by an organization. To ask for the
list of organizations and their domains stored by SortingHat,
a GraphQL query would be like this:

```
{
  organizations {
    name
    domains {
      domain
      isTopDomain
    }
  }
}
```

GraphQL support is provided by `graphene` and `graphene_django`
libraries. The project configuration has been modified to

[graphql] Define GraphQL mutation to add identities

The mutation 'addIdentity' allows to add a new identity
to the registry. These identities can be added to
an existing unique identity. By defualt, a new unique
identity will be created which each new identity.

Errors are returned in case the identity already exists,
when the unique identity to link the new identity
does not exist or when any parameter has an invalid value.

To add an identity a mutation query like this will work:

mutation addId(
  $source: String,
  $name: String,
  $email: String,
  $username: String
  $uuid: String) {
  addIdentity(
    source: $source
    name: $name
    email: $email
    username: $username
    uuid: $uuid) {
      uuid
      identity {
        id
        name
        email
        username
        source
      }
    }
  }

[models] Rename ModelBase class to EntityBase

This class creates two fields, `created_at` and `last_modified`.
This means every new model inheriting from it will have these two
fields by default. So far, these fields have been needed in all
the models but we could need new ones without these default
fields.

This class should still be the base for all the models related
to entities (`Organization`, `Domain`, `Idenitity`, etc.).

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[models] Add Transaction and Operation classes

`Transaction` class is meant to represent objects which are
created inside a context (e.g., a method from the API)
where the database is going to be modified in some way.
The `name` parameter is a choice field which is related with
the name of the method creating the transaction.

`Operation` class is meant to represent atomic interactions
with the database (either add, delete or update something)
and the entities which are involved in this interaction
(identities, organizations, domains, enrollments, etc.).
An `Operation` object is including the original arguments
from the method creating the operation.

Note that the type of allowed operations from `Operation`
class are defined in an inner *enum* class named `OpTypeChoice`.

The new file `0002_log.py` file is the result of applying the
new migrations after the changes in `models.py`.

As `Operation` model is using the JSONField from `django_mysql`
module, it is now added to the `requirements.txt` file as a new
dependency.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[errors] Add ClosedTransactionError

This error raises when attempting to modify a transaction that
was already closed; that is a given `Transaction` object with
a `closed_at` date and the field `is_closed` set to `True`.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[log] Add TransactionsLog class

This new class creates new `TransactionsLog` objects, generating

`closed_at` date to that Transaction object and also
a boolean flag.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

Now, every DB method must be called under a certain transaction

Every method adding, deleting or updating any entity in the

including its input arguments, the type of modification, the
entity/entities involved, a timestamp, the targeted entity
and the related transaction.

Several unit tests were also modified to include the addition of a
mandatory transaction in many `db.py` methods, including some tests
in `test_schema.py`.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add queries for `Transactions` and `Operations`

These new queries allow to export the list of transactions
and operations from the database with the following format:

query {
    transactions {
      name
      createdAt
      tuid
      isClosed
      closedAt
    }
}

query {
    operations {
      ouid
      opType
      entityType
      target
      timestamp
      args
      trx {
        name
        createdAt
      }
    }
}

Both queries support filtering for most of the fields from
their corresponding models, including `from_date` and `to_date`
filters for both models (referencing to `created_at` field
for transactions and `timestamp` for operations). This date
can be passed as filter as a string following ISO 8601 format.

As the `args` field from `Operations` model is encoded in a
serialized JSON, it was necessary to define a explicit conversion
to return these encoded JSON fields as dictionaries. The class
in charge of this process is named `OperationArgsType` and it
inherits from `GenericScalar` class, which is a basic type defined
in `graphene` module representing a generic GraphQL scalar value
that could be String, Boolean, Int, Float, List or Object.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add support for pagination to exisiting queries

Pagination for query results has been implemented on top of
the `Paginator` object from Django and applied to the existing
queries.

When performing a query, there are two new parameters:
- `pageSize`: Number of elements we want to obtain per page.
 If `pageSize` value is not set, the value will be set using
 a configuration parameter defined in Django settings, named
 `DEFAULT_GRAPHQL_PAGE_SIZE`.
- `page`: Number of the page we are asking for.
 If `page` value is not set, it will return the first page
 by default.

These changes modify the structure of the queries. Now, the
returned objects will be given under `entities`, and the
information related with the pagination under `pageInfo`.
For instance, to ask for a list of unique identities using
pagination, the query would look like this:

```
{
  uidentities(
    page: 2
    pageSize: 5
  ){
    entities{
      uuid
    }
    pageInfo{
      page
      pageSize
      numPages
      hasNext
      hasPrev
      startIndex
      endIndex
      totalResults
    }
  }
}
```

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[config] Hide Tracebacks caused by controlled Graphene errors

After this change, the logger object from Graphene has been
set to show only Fatal/Critical errors.

In Graphene-Django module, all the exceptions raised which are
caused by a GraphQL execution returns a result detailing the
errors. However, even if the exception is properly captured,
a Traceback is printed to STDERR where the Django `manage.py`
server is executed.

This was producing undesired error messages whenever a query
caused a controlled error like, for instance, adding a
duplicated entry to the database.

There is not an official solution for this problem yet, so we
decided to go for this workaround, as the Traceback is not
displayed anymore but the query result is still including the
information from results.errors, including what caused the
error or exception when executing the query.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add support for authenticated queries

These changes add support for performing authenticated queries
(both GraphQL queries and mutations), based on JSON Web Tokens
(JWT).

To perform an authenticated query, an existing user must
generate a token which has to be included in the `Authorization`
header with the HTTP request. This token is generated using a
mutation which comes defined by the `graphene-jwt` module,
together with other extra mutations for verifying an existing
token and refreshing it in case the token expired.

By default, all the queries and mutations now require
authentication. This is controlled by a custom decorator named
`check_auth` which is based on the pre-defined decorator
`login_required` and extending it to check both if the `user`
object from the `context.info` object is authenticated and the
value of a new control variable named `AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED`,
defined in Django settings allowing to set whether authentication
is required or not.

If the user is not logged or uses an invalid token, the following
exception is raised:

```
graphql.error.located_error.GraphQLLocatedError: You do not have
permission to perform this action
```

Note: After these changes, the `AUTHENTICATION_REQUIRED` variable
in the testing configuration script must be set to `True`.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[recommendations] Add affiliation recommendations

The function recommend_affiliations() generates a list
of organizations when individuals can be enrolled.
The recommendations are based on the email addreses
of the individuals and the domains of the organizations.

The function checks if the domains of these email
addresses of an individual match with any of the
domains stored on the registry. If this is the case,
the organization associated to that domain will be
recommended.

[recommendations] Add recommendations engine class

The class `RecommendationEngine` allows to generate
a list of recommendations of a certain type.

The recommendations are returned in `Recommendation`
objects. This object is a tuple that contains a key
and a type to identify it, and a list of suggestions.

Right now, the only type supported is 'affiliation'.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[jobs] Add affiliation job

The affiliation process consist on get which organizations
are valid for an individual (using recommendations) and
enroll it to them. The job will get as an input a list
of individuals identifiers.

As 'affiliation' is a long process it will run in a jobs
queue. The scheduler selected to manage these tasks is 'rq'.
It has an extension for Django ('django-rq') that allows
to visualize the queues, workers and the status of the
jobs. It also needs Redis to handle the communications
between workers and queues.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[log] Add job id to the name of the transaction

If the context contains a job identifier, the transaction
will include it as a suffix to its name. Therefore,
it will be possible to determine when a transaction
was created by a job.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[jobs] Add function to find jobs in the registry

This function allows to look for a job in the registry
using its identifier.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add mutation to affiliate individuals

The mutation will schedule a job to affiliate all the
individuals defined by any of the keys passed in `uuids`
argument. When no keys are given, all the individuals
on the registry will be affiliate.

The mutation returns the identifier of the scheduled job.
With this id it will be able to check later the job status
and if its results are ready.

This is an example of the call in GraphQL to
the mutation:

mutation affiliate($uuids: [String]) {
    affiliate(uuids: $uuids) {
        jobId
    }
}

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add job query

This query retrieves the status of a job. The data
returned contain the id of the job, its status, and
the results of its execution.

Within the data, there is also the field `errors`,
which stores any error raised during the process.

As the data in the results field may be different
depending of the type of job, this field has been
declared as `graphene.Union`. This allows to return
different kind of results. Right now, there is only
one type available: `AffiliationResultType`.

The type `AffiliationResultType` stores the uuid
of the individual and a list with the organizations
it was enrolled to during the affiliation process
run by the job.

This is an example of job query to get the results
generated by an affiliation job:

```
{
  job(
    jobId:"1234-5678-90AB-CDEF"
  ){
    jobId
    status
    errors
    result {
      __typename
      ... on AffiliationResultType {
          uuid
          organizations
      }
    }
  }
}
```

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

[recommendations] Identity matches based on a list of individuals

The function checks if any identity from each individual matches
with a given set of target individuals. First, it filters by the
fields from the criteria and then it groups the matches by
identity. Then, these groups are turned into sets of matching
identities found among all the input identities set.

Each recommendation contains the uuid of the individual provided
in the input list and a list with the matching individuals or
the matching identities if the `verbose` option is activated.

When no matching is found for a given individual, an empty list
will be returned for that individual.

The method returns a generator of identity matches
recommendations.

The algorithm implementing the matching uses `pandas` module,
which has been added to `requirements.txt` file.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[engine] Add recommendation type for identitity matches

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[jobs] Get matching identities recommendations from sets of individuals

This function generates a list of recommendations which include the
matching identities from the individuals which can be merged with.
This job returns a dictionary with which individuals are recommended
to be merged to which individual (or which identities is `verbose`
mode is activated).

Individuals both for `source_uuids` and `target_uuids` are defined by
any of their valid keys or UUIDs. When the parameter `target_uuids`
is empty, the job will take all the individuals stored in the registry,
so matches will be found comparing the identities from the individuals
in `source_uuids` against all the identities on the registry.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

Merge branch 'muggle_matching' of 'https://github.com/mafesan/grimoirelab-sortinghat'

Merges #308
Closes #308
Fixes #307

[recommendations] Remove key UUID from matching results

Before this change, an UUID used as a key could be included
in the set of matching results. Now, it is filtered out
before returning the results.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[matching] Improve matching recommendations method

When the method receives an empty list of `target_uuids`, the
whole set of identities was retrieved in an inefficient way, as
the former input was a query set with all the individuals on the
registry. Each individual caused two queries, one for retrieving
the individual object and another one for getting its identities.
This was slowing down the performance heavily.

Now, in this case all the identities from the registry are
retrieved with a single, more efficient query.

Before this change, the `target_uuids` were retrieved at `jobs`
level. Now, the `recommend_matches` method is in charge of this
operation.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[matching] Fix typo in method docstrings

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[errors] Add EqualIndividualError

This error should be raised when the source and destination
individual for a given operation are the same.

Before this change, this error was raised as an `InvalidValueError`.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[jobs] Unify matching identities from recommendation results

This function automates the identities unify process obtaining a
list of recommendations where matching individuals can be merged.
After that, matching individuals are merged.
This job returns a list with the individuals which have been merged
and the errors generated during this process.

Individuals both for `source_uuids` and `target_uuids` are defined
by any of their valid keys or UUIDs. When the parameter
`target_uuids` is empty, the job will take all the individuals
stored in the registry, so matches will be found comparing the
identities from the individuals in `source_uuids` against all the
identities on the registry.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[schema] Support filtering individuals by last updated date

The accepted formats are controlled by regular expressions
matching two patterns:
* A comparison operator (>, >=, <, <=) and a date
(e.g. `>=YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
* A range operator (..) between two dates
(e.g. `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ..YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`)

The accepted date format is ISO 8601, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ,
also accepting microseconds and time zone offset
(YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.ms+HH:HH).

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[api] Add method for updating enrollment dates

The method updates atomically an individual's enrollment or
set of enrollments defined by the initial date range to a new
date range.

As in the enroll method wider date ranges get merged into
the wider one, this method uses the `withdraw` and the `enroll`
API methods to apply these steps:
 * Withdraw the enrollments from the provided organization and
   an existing date range.
 * Set a new enrollment to that same organization with the new
   date range.

By default, the `force` parameter is set to `True`, as it
overwrites default dates in case a more specific date is provided
when the updated enrollment is added using the `enroll` API
method internally.

In case any of the new dates are missing, the former value for
that date will be preserved. If both new dates are missing,
the method will raise an `InvalidValueError`.

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[schema] Add mutation for update enrollment dates

The mutation update atomically an individual's enrollment
or set of enrollments defined by the initial date range to
a new date range.

As in the enroll method wider date ranges get merged into
the wider one, this method withdraws the enrollments from
the old date range and set a new enrollment with the new
date range. By default, the `force` parameter is set to
`True`, as it overwrites default dates in case a more
specific date is provided when the updated enrollment is
added.

In case any of the new dates are missing, the former
value for that date will be preserved.

Example for the new mutation:

```
mutation {
  updateEnrollment(uuid': '3283e58(...)',
          'organization': 'Example',
          'fromDate': '2012-01-01T00:00:00+0000',
          'toDate': '2014-01-01T00:00:00+0000',
          'newFromDate': '2012-01-02T00:00:00+0000',
          'newToDate': '2013-12-31T00:00:00+0000'){
    uuid
    individual {
      mk
      enrollments {
        organization {
          name
        }
      start
      end
      }
    }
  }
}
```

Signed-off-by: Miguel Ángel Fernández <mafesan@bitergia.com>

[log] Prevent to overwrite log objects when ids are reused

With the current code, transactions or operations objects
will be overwritten in the database if the same id is used.

This patch fixes the problem using the option 'force_insert'
on 'save()' calls. When this option is activated, it will
run 'INSERT' queries instead of 'UPDATE'. If an object already
has the same id, the engine will raise an IntegrityError
exception because the entity will be duplicated.

This patch adds the proper unit tests.

[server] Define settings using enviroment variables

This commit adds a set of standard environment variables
that can be set to configure the service. These varibles
are:

  - SORTINGHAT_ALLOWED_HOST: to define the sites
    the server is allow to serve. Avoids HTTP host
    header attacks.
  - SORTINGHAT_CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS: to set the sites
    that can request resources from the server.
  - SORTINGHAT_DB_(HOST, PORT, USER, PASSWORD, DATABASE):
    which are the parameters neccessary to access the
    database.
  - SORTINGHAT_HTTP_DEV: with the address to start
    a HTTP server for developing and testing.
  - SORTINGHAT_GENDERIZE_API_KEY: to use this token or key
    to access genderize.io API.

Signed-off-by: Santiago Dueñas <sduenas@bitergia.com>

Config genderize

[server] Activate debugging when development mode is set

When the '--dev' flag is given, the server runs in
development mode but Django will run on debug mode
only when DEBUG setting is set to True. To avoid that
confusion, we decided that DEBUG will be always active
when the server runs in development mode.

[database] Allow SSL connections

The engine was not configure to accept SSL connections.
With this patch, the database module will try to establish
a SSL connection first. If this is not possible, it will
try to communicate with the server with a non-secure
connection.

To set the SSL connection, it was necessary a minor hack
that consists on passing an non-empty dictionary with key
'ssl' in 'connect_args'. The module pymysql expects a dict
with some SSL paramters, which will force to use specific
cert o ca. As we do not want that, we found that passing
a dict with a random key is valid and pymsql ignores that
key but enforces a SSL connection.

[db-model] Remove CoerceToBool type

This code fixes the bug #121, thus it removes the type
CoerceToBool (introduced at 5f69ed8), which was used to handle
string representations of boolean values (i.e., True and False)
for SqlAlchemy versions prior to 1.1.14. This was due to the fact
that SqlAlchemy versions 1.1.x defined the Boolean type as follows:
```
Boolean typically uses BOOLEAN or SMALLINT on the DDL side,
and on the Python side deals in True or False.
```

Thus, equivalent string representations weren't handled
and required the definition of the CoerceToBool (which created an
additional CHECK constraint).

From versions greater than >=1.2.0 (already set in the current setup.py),
the CoerceToBool isn't needed anymore and can be removed. In particular, the
Boolean type is now defined as:
```
The Boolean datatype currently has two levels of assertion that the values
persisted are simple true/false values. For all backends, only the Python
values None, True, False, 1 or 0 are accepted as parameter values. For those
backends that don’t support a “native boolean” datatype, a CHECK constraint
is also created on the target column. Production of the CHECK constraint
can be disabled by passing the Boolean.create_constraint flag set to False
```

Tests have been updated accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Valerio Cosentino <valcos@bitergia.com>

[tests] Fix `test_not_null_source` in test_model

This code fixes the test `test_not_null_source` by adding
the id, which is mandatory. This fix is needed to
prevent the error:
```
sqlalchemy.exc.InternalError: (pymysql.err.InternalError)
(1364, "Field 'id' doesn't have a default value")
```

Due to:
```
sqlalchemy/sql/crud.py:695: SAWarning: Column 'identities.id' is
marked as a member of the primary key for table 'identities', but
has no Python-side or server-side default generator indicated,
nor does it indicate 'autoincrement=True' or 'nullable=True',
and no explicit value is passed.
Primary key columns typically may not store NULL.
```

Signed-off-by: Valerio Cosentino <valcos@bitergia.com>

[sortinghat/utils] Fix merge_date_ranges

This code fixes when we have two dates and in the first the `end`
date is the same as the `start` date of the second and the `end`
date is MAX_PERIOD_DATE. They both have the same organization.

For instance:
```
- organization: Chaoss
  start: 2000-01-01
  end: 2001-01-01
- organization: Chaoss
  start: 2001-01-01
  end: 2100-01-01
```

The current behavior only creates one enrollment (the first one)
due to the `st` is the same as `saved[1]` and the `en` is
MAX_PERIOD_DATE. Thus, the `saved[1] = min(saved[1], en)` and the
second enrollment is merged wrongly.
```
Enrollments:
  Chaoss 2000-01-01 00:00:00 2001-01-01 00:00:00
```

The fix behavior will create two enrollments because when the
`st` is not less than instead of less than or equal to `saved[1]`
it will create a new one.
```
Enrollments:
  Chaoss 2000-01-01 00:00:00 2001-01-01 00:00:00
  Chaoss 2001-01-01 00:00:00 2100-01-01 00:00:00
```

Test updated accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Quan Zhou <quan@bitergia.com>
